question: Question 1-09/14/2016 Which ONE of the following is true concerning the differences between prompt and delayed neutrons

answers.answer: a. Prompt neutrons account for less than one percent of the neutron population while delayed neutrons account for approximately ninety-nine percent of the neutron population.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reactor Training Manual, Page 2-16.

answers.answer: b. Prompt neutrons are released during fast fissions while delayed neutrons are released during thermal fissions.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reactor Training Manual, Page 2-16.

answers.answer: c. Prompt neutrons are released during the fission process while delayed neutrons are released during the decay of fission products.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: d. Prompt neutrons are the dominating factor in determining the reactor period while delayed neutrons have little effect on the reactor period.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reactor Training Manual, Page 2-16.

question: QUESTION 2-09/14/2016 A reactor scram has resulted in the instantaneous insertion of .006 ∆K/K of negative reactivity. Which one of the following is the stable negative reactor period resulting from the scram?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 4.6,
Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 4.6,
Correct.
Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 4.6,

question: Question 3-09/14/2016 Which ONE of the following isotopes has the largest microscopic cross-section for absorption for thermal neutrons?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh, J. “Introduction to Nuclear Engineering” p. 738 Sm149 (41,000 b); U235 (687 b); Xe135 (2.65 x 106 b); B10 (3840 b)
Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh, J. “Introduction to Nuclear Engineering” p. 738 Sm149 (41,000 b); U235 (687 b); Xe135 (2.65 x 106 b); B10 (3840 b)
Correct.
Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh, J. “Introduction to Nuclear Engineering” p. 738 Sm149 (41,000 b); U235 (687 b); Xe135 (2.65 x 106 b); B10 (3840 b)

question: QUESTION 4-09/14/2016 When the excess reactivity (Kex) exceeds the delayed neutron fraction (β), a reactor is said to be:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Bevelacqua, J. 2009. Basic Health Physics. p.391
Incorrect. REF: Bevelacqua, J. 2009. Basic Health Physics. p.391

answers.answer: c. Within its shutdown margin requirements
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Bevelacqua, J. 2009. Basic Health Physics. p.391
Correct.

question: QUESTION 5-09/14/2016 Complete the following sentence. a dollar ($) is a unit of reactivity, where one dollar ($1) is equal to the ____.

answers.answer: a. Delayed neutron precursor decay constant (λ).
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reactor Theory (Neutron Characteristics) DOE-HDBK-1019/1-93 PROMPT AND DELAYED NEUTRON

answers.answer: b. Effective delayed neutron precursor decay constant (λeff).
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reactor Theory (Neutron Characteristics) DOE-HDBK-1019/1-93 PROMPT AND DELAYED NEUTRON
Incorrect. REF: Reactor Theory (Neutron Characteristics) DOE-HDBK-1019/1-93 PROMPT AND DELAYED NEUTRON
Correct.

question: QUESTION 6-09/14/2016 In accordance with the PSBR Technical Specifications, the term
describes:

answers.answer: a. the time required for the rods to fully insert.
answers.feedback: Incorrect REF: PSBR Technical Specifications, Section 1.1.42.
Incorrect REF: PSBR Technical Specifications, Section 1.1.42.

answers.answer: c. the amount of subcriticality, considering the worth of all rods.
answers.feedback: Incorrect REF: PSBR Technical Specifications, Section 1.1.42.

answers.answer: d. the amount of subcriticality with the most reactive rod fully withdrawn.
answers.feedback: Correct.

question: QUESTION 7-09/14/2016 The count rate is 50 cps. An experimenter inserts an experiment into the core, and the count rate decreases to 25 cps. Given the initial Keff of the reactor was 0.8, what is the worth of the experiment?

answers.feedback: Correct.
Incorrect. CR1 / CR2 = (1 – Keff2) / (1 – Keff1) → 50 / 25 = (1 – Keff2) / (1 – 0.8). Therefore Keff2 = 0.6. ∆ρ = Keff2 – Keff1 / Keff2 · Keff1 = (0.6 – 0.8)/(0.6 · 0.8) = - 0.41667.
Incorrect. CR1 / CR2 = (1 – Keff2) / (1 – Keff1) → 50 / 25 = (1 – Keff2) / (1 – 0.8). Therefore Keff2 = 0.6. ∆ρ = Keff2 – Keff1 / Keff2 · Keff1 = (0.6 – 0.8)/(0.6 · 0.8) = - 0.41667.
Incorrect. CR1 / CR2 = (1 – Keff2) / (1 – Keff1) → 50 / 25 = (1 – Keff2) / (1 – 0.8). Therefore Keff2 = 0.6. ∆ρ = Keff2 – Keff1 / Keff2 · Keff1 = (0.6 – 0.8)/(0.6 · 0.8) = - 0.41667.

question: QUESTION 9-09/14/2016 A nuclear reactor startup is being performed by adding equal amounts of positive reactivity and waiting for neutron population to stabilize. As the reactor approaches criticality, the numerical change in stable neutron population after each reactivity addition, and the time required for the neutron population to stabilize after each reactivity addition.

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Question ID #P1766, NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank—PWR2010
Correct.

answers.answer: c. remains the same; remains the same.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Question ID #P1766, NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank—PWR2010
Incorrect. REF: Question ID #P1766, NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank—PWR2010

question: QUESTION 10-09/14/2016 Complete the following sentence. In a nuclear reactor, 95% of all Xenon production is directly produced through the.

answers.feedback: Correct.
Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Vol. 2
Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Vol. 2
Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Vol. 2

question: QUESTION 11-09/14/2016 As primary coolant temperature increases, control rod worth:

answers.answer: a. decreases due to lower reflector efficiency.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reactor Training Manual - Reactivity Feedback

answers.answer: b. decreases due to higher neutron absorption in the moderator.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reactor Training Manual - Reactivity Feedback

answers.answer: c. increases due to the increase in thermal diffusion length.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: d. remains the same due to constant poison cross-section of the control rods.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reactor Training Manual - Reactivity Feedback

question: QUESTION 12-09/14/2016 Excess reactivity is the amount of reactivity:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone and Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Chapter 5, Section 5.114

answers.answer: b. needed to achieve prompt criticality.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone and Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Chapter 5, Section 5.114

answers.answer: c. available above that which is required to make the reactor subcritical.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone and Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Chapter 5, Section 5.114

answers.answer: d. available above that which is required to keep the reactor critical.
answers.feedback: Correct.

question: QUESTION 13-09/14/2016 You are conducting a reactor startup after installing 2 new fuel assemblies in the core. Given the following rod withdrawal data, estimate the rod position when criticality would occur. The initial count rate on the nuclear instrumentation prior to rod withdrawal is 55 cps. Rod Withdrawal (Inches) vs. Count Rate (cps): 0 in 55 cps, 2 in 58 cps, 4 in 60 cps, 6 in 61 cps, 8 in 69 cps, 10 in 85 cps 12 in 275 cps

answers.feedback: Incorrect.
Correct.
Incorrect.
Incorrect.

question: QUESTION 14-09/14/2016 You are performing a 50 Watt Critical Rod Position. Given the following data, calculate what the Shutdown Margin, as defined by Technical Specifications, is in a clean cold core. Control Rod, Total Worth, Cirtical Worth: Transient $2.92 $1.75, Safety $3.97 $2.63, Shim $2.85 $1.84, Regulating $2.92 $1.81, Total $12.66 $8.03

answers.feedback: Incorrect. SDM = Critical worth – Most reactive Rod worth remaining out of core. SDM = 8.03-3.97 = $4.06. PSU Exam Reference Material (Adapted CP-11 data)
Incorrect. SDM = Critical worth – Most reactive Rod worth remaining out of core. SDM = 8.03-3.97 = $4.06. PSU Exam Reference Material (Adapted CP-11 data)
Correct.
Incorrect. SDM = Critical worth – Most reactive Rod worth remaining out of core. SDM = 8.03-3.97 = $4.06. PSU Exam Reference Material (Adapted CP-11 data)

question:
QUESTION 15-09/14/2016 In a subcritical reactor, K eff is increased from 0.861 to 0.946. Which ONE of the
following is the amount of reactivity that was added to the reactor core?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reactor Training Manual - Reactor Kinectics.
Correct.
Incorrect. REF: Reactor Training Manual - Reactor Kinectics.
Incorrect. REF: Reactor Training Manual - Reactor Kinectics.

question: QUESTION 16-09/14/2016 If reactor power is increasing by a decade every minute, it has a period of:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991. P = Poet/T. 10 = 1e60/T. ln 10 = 60/T. 2.3 = 60/T. T = 60/2.3. T = 26 seconds.
Correct
Incorrect. Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991. P = Poet/T. 10 = 1e60/T. ln 10 = 60/T. 2.3 = 60/T. T = 60/2.3. T = 26 seconds.
Incorrect. Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991. P = Poet/T. 10 = 1e60/T. ln 10 = 60/T. 2.3 = 60/T. T = 60/2.3. T = 26 seconds.

question: QUESTION 17-09/14/2016 With the reactor critical at 10 KW a rod is pulled to insert a positive reactivity of $0.18. Which one of the following will be the stable reactor period as a result of this reactivity insertion?

answers.feedback: Incorrect.
Correct.
Incorrect.

question: QUESTION 18-09/14/2016 Which ONE of the following conditions will INCREASE the core excess of a reactor?

answers.answer: a. Higher moderator temperature (assume negative temperature coefficient).
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Vol. 2.

answers.answer: b. Insertion of a negative reactivity worth experiment.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Vol. 2.

answers.answer: c. Burnout of a burnable poison.
answers.feedback: Correct.
Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Vol. 2.

question: QUESTION 19-09/14/2016 Following the reactor started up and it has been at 100% power for 3 hours. The Reactor Operator notes that several small control rod withdrawals are required to maintain power at 100%. Which of the following is the reason for the rod withdrawals?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reactor Training Manual - Reactor Physics and Kinetics.

answers.answer: b. Xenon is building in to equilibrium concentration.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: c. Pool water temperatures are decreasing.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reactor Training Manual - Reactor Physics and Kinetics.

answers.answer: d. Samarium is burning out from equilibrium concentration.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reactor Training Manual - Reactor Physics and Kinetics.

question: QUESTION 20-09/14/2016 Given: Primary coolant flow rate is 500 gallons/minute and secondary flow rate is 700 gallons/minute. The ∆T across the primary side of the heat exchanger is 13̊F and secondary inlet temperature to the heat exchanger is 73̊F. Assuming both the primary and secondary coolants have the same Cp value, which ONE of the following is the secondary outlet temperature?

answers.feedback: Correct.
Incorrect. ∆Tsec= (Flowpri/Flowsec) x ∆Tpri. ∆Tsec= (500/700) x 13°F = 9.28°F. Secondary outlet = 73°F + 9.28°F = 82.3°F.
Incorrect. ∆Tsec= (Flowpri/Flowsec) x ∆Tpri. ∆Tsec= (500/700) x 13°F = 9.28°F. Secondary outlet = 73°F + 9.28°F = 82.3°F.
Incorrect. ∆Tsec= (Flowpri/Flowsec) x ∆Tpri. ∆Tsec= (500/700) x 13°F = 9.28°F. Secondary outlet = 73°F + 9.28°F = 82.3°F.
